meanings.definition: To die through submersion in and inhalation of water.
meanings.sent1: The poor man fell into the river and started to drown.
meanings.sent2: Swimming in the deep end without help can lead to drowning.
meanings.sent3: The fish tried to teach the cat to swim, but it almost drowned in the bowl.
meanings.sent4: Her sorrows threatened to drown her in a sea of despair.
meanings.sent5: The loud noise of the waterfall made it seem like the rocks would drown in the rushing water.

meanings.definition: To overwhelm with a large amount of something.
meanings.sent1: The loud music at the party can drown out any conversation.
meanings.sent2: The cheers of the crowd can drown the sound of the referee's whistle.
meanings.sent3: The delicious smell of the bakery can drown you in cravings.
meanings.sent4: The bright lights of the city can drown the stars in the night sky.
meanings.sent5: The heavy rain can drown the sound of footsteps on the pavement.

meanings.definition: To be covered or flooded with a liquid.
meanings.sent1: The fields can drown in water after heavy rain.
meanings.sent2: The boat started to drown as the waves crashed over it.
meanings.sent3: The ice cream was so melted that it seemed to drown in the bowl.
meanings.sent4: The city streets can drown in a sea of colorful confetti during a parade.
meanings.sent5: The garden can drown in beauty when the flowers bloom in spring.
